lead_paragraph: As Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin scrambled to save faltering markets at the start of the pandemic last year, America’s top economic officials were in near-constant contact with a Wall Street executive whose firm stood to benefit financially from the rescue.

headline: The Hills Are Alive With the Flows of Physics
keywords: ['Geology', 'Soil', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Physics', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Landscapes around you may appear static, but research using lasers suggests even the most steady terrain is creeping along.
lead_paragraph: Mountains look solid. But that just might be a mirage. On extremely long timescales, natural landscapes are creeping and flowing like viscous streams.

headline: What Did New York’s Primaries Mean for Progressives? It’s Complicated.
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Elections, District Attorneys', 'Elections, Comptrollers', 'Elections, City Councils', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: Progressives cheered the results in down-ballot races and in Buffalo, even as the outcome of the mayoral primary appeared less rosy.
lead_paragraph: They may not win Gracie Mansion, but there’s always Buffalo. And Rochester, too.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: After the pandemic, a lot of New Yorkers may be hooked on outdoor shows. And have they not done something to remind us of how deeply nestled music is into the city’s identity? At the same time, some old pillars of the scene remain in place — and with clubs open at full capacity, watching Greenwich Village rev back to life is a welcome sight.

headline: Your Summer Binge List: 10 Shows You Might Have Missed
abstract: Now there’s time for some things that flew under the school-year radar.
lead_paragraph: Wherever you spent the 2020-21 school year — in class, or texting while pretending to listen to Zoom lectures, or working while trying to get your children to listen to their Zoom lectures — there were distractions stealing time from your television viewing. Maybe your bandwidth extended only as far as the buzziest series — “The Queen’s Gambit” or “90 Day Fiancé.” Now that summer’s here, we’re offering a selection of worthwhile shows that kept a lower profile this past season. From an old-fashioned network sitcom to a wacky anime sending up yakuza movies, here are 10 things to catch up on now that you have the time to binge.

headline: 10 Million Data Requests: How Our Covid Team Tracked the Pandemic
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The project began 18 months ago as a simple concept: Count every known U.S. case at the time. When the virus grew exponentially, so did the efforts to document it.
lead_paragraph: As of this morning, programs written by New York Times developers have made more than 10 million requests for Covid-19 data from websites around the world. The data we’re collecting are daily snapshots of the virus’s ebb and flow, including for every U.S. state and thousands of U.S. counties, cities and ZIP codes.

headline: Hold the Tequila. The Sunrise Is All Some Travelers Need.
abstract: As vaccination levels rise and Americans head back to the roads and skies, sober travel, a subset of vacations once relegated to 12-steppers and recovering addicts, is going mainstream.
lead_paragraph: One year into the coronavirus pandemic, after months of gaining weight and feeling groggy, Mayra Ramirez stopped drinking. And this summer, she’ll mark a new milestone for her sobriety: a completely alcohol-free vacation.

headline: Wildfires Threaten Urban Water Supplies, Long After the Flames Are Out
abstract: After a forest burns, the resulting erosion can contaminate drinking water supplies for up to a decade.
lead_paragraph: BELLVUE, Colo. — Wrangling a 25-foot-long tube of straw up a steep hillside studded with charred pine trees, three volunteer workers placed it in a shallow trench that had been dug along the slope.

headline: For Pride This Weekend, You Do You
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: There are plenty of ways to celebrate, from several grass-roots marches to a 10K run with beer tastings.
lead_paragraph: With its corporate logos, television coverage and please-the-crowds spirit, the NYC Pride March — even in its abbreviated format this year — is not for everyone. “Real pride is not rainbow capitalism,” said Sarah Hallonquist, an entrepreneur and activist who described the term “real pride” as one “for queer people, by queer people, planned by queer activists,” and one that embraces all socio-economic groups, including working-class people. “Every single person has a voice in what’s being said.”

keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Asheville, N.C., has been among the hardest hit by police departures in the wake of last year’s George Floyd protests. About a third of the force quit or retired.
lead_paragraph: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — As protests surged across the country last year over the death of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, Officer Lindsay C. Rose in Asheville, N.C., found her world capsized.

lead_paragraph: The most widely used coronavirus vaccines are designed as two-shot inoculations, and nearly everyone worldwide who has had both doses has received the same vaccine both times.

headline: Brazil Passes 500,000 Covid Deaths, a Tragedy With No Sign of Letup
abstract: With 2.7 percent of the world’s population, Brazil has suffered 13 percent of the Covid-19 fatalities, and the pandemic there is not abating.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazilians were recovering from Carnival in the heady days of February 2020 when the first known carriers of the new coronavirus flew home from Europe, planting the seeds of catastrophe.

headline: Antitrust Overhaul Passes Its First Tests. Now, the Hard Parts.

But the outcomes of the votes, and the debates before they took place, also showed divisions among lawmakers — and underscored why final passage of the package is expected to be difficult.

keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'audio-neutral-informative']
abstract: How an export ban has left millions of people without coronavirus vaccines and imperiled the reputation of the Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine maker.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus hit, the Serum Institute of India seemed uniquely positioned to help.

headline: Extended Warranties for Cars Are ‘Fraught With Peril for Consumers’
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Automobiles', 'Consumer Protection', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Content Type: Service', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telemarketing']
abstract: While reputable options exist, the robocalls are almost certainly scams, an industry group warns. And for consumers who feel they have been ripped off, there is no guarantee anyone will help.
lead_paragraph: Nat Pope has spent much of his academic career studying extended car warranties, such as those seen on television and pushed in robocalls promising to pay for costly repairs. But here’s what he still doesn’t know: Who can help if there’s a problem with the warranty?

headline: As Stick Shifts Fade Into Obscurity, Collectors See Opportunity
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Auctions', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Cars with manual transmissions, even late models, are holding their value as the collector market hunts for rarity.
lead_paragraph: They’re not extinct yet, but the end is coming for stick-shift cars.

headline: The Effects of Climate Change
abstract: They’re growing more apparent. But there are reasons to be hopeful.
lead_paragraph: Climate change has plunged the Western U.S. into its worst drought in two decades. And a record-breaking heat wave only made things worse.

headline: ‘Lansky’ Review: A Mobster Burnishes His Legacy
abstract: Harvey Keitel stars as the underworld financial wizard in this dramatization.
lead_paragraph: The best thing in “Lansky” is Harvey Keitel’s turn as the gangster Meyer Lansky. Eager to change the popular perception of his career, and dying of lung cancer, he agrees to tell his story to a writer in 1981.

headline: ‘Werewolves Within’ Review: Small-Town Chaos
abstract: Ideological disagreements sever a hamlet in this breakneck horror comedy. Also, there is probably a werewolf.
lead_paragraph: Horror villains have always shouldered a lot of cultural baggage, but there have been attempts to reclaim monstrosity on film, particularly in the last few decades of low-budget cinema. “Ginger Snaps” famously linked lycanthropy and menstruation, “Raw” turned carnal desire into cannibalism and “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night” offered a female vampire vigilante. “Werewolves Within,” a horror comedy from the director Josh Ruben, comes so close to operating on this level — before it makes a beeline for the status quo.

headline: ‘God Exists, Her Name Is Petrunya’ Review: Her Cross to Bear
abstract: An unemployed historian living with her parents in a Macedonia town crashes an all-male Orthodox Christian ceremony and enacts a one-woman feminist resistance.
lead_paragraph: In another world, the rebellious title character of “God Exists, Her Name Is Petrunya” might have been a contented free spirit in a John Waters movie. But Petrunya lives in the conservative town of Stip, Macedonia, and she seems dulled into a standstill by patriarchal rules and motherly interference. That starts to change when she crashes an all-male Orthodox ceremony — every year, a priest lobs a cross into a river and men scramble to grab it — and takes the prize.

headline: ‘Rebel Hearts’ Review: Sisters Act Up
abstract: This flashy, feel-good documentary follows a group of progressive Catholic nuns in 1960s Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Few institutions notoriously resist change like the Roman Catholic Church, which to this day upholds rules of celibacy and continues to forbid the ordination of women. So for some, it may be surprising to learn that the church’s iron-fisted rule has long been met with resistance.

headline: ‘Kenny Scharf: When Worlds Collide’ Review: Outlasting an Art Scene
keywords: ['Art', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: A new documentary co-directed by the artist’s daughter shows how Scharf, a poster boy for downtown New York art in the ’80s, is hard at work decades later.
lead_paragraph: The condition of being an artist and the significance of what an artist produces are two distinct things. The post-pop artist Kenny Scharf, who came out of the same downtown art and music scene as Keith Haring, Jean-Michel Basquiat and Klaus Nomi, is someone whose critical and material stock has risen, fallen and risen again over decades. The documentary “Kenny Scharf: When Worlds Collide,” directed by Max Basch and the artist’s daughter Malia Scharf, makes a considered and not entirely uncritical case for Scharf’s relevance.

headline: ‘False Positive’ Review: Pregnancy Scares
abstract: This Hulu horror movie is a tepid, scattered look at the dark side of childbirth starring the “Broad City” co-creator Ilana Glazer.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, mainstream horror movies like “Hereditary” and “It Follows” have embraced a seemingly more sophisticated form that unites social and psychological drama with a sleek visual sensibility. But possessing these ingredients does not a winner make. Case in point: “False Positive,” a handsome new Hulu feature that aspires to be a modern version of “Rosemary’s Baby,” but that ultimately lands somewhere between tepid and confused.

headline: ‘My Heart Can’t Beat Unless You Tell It To’ Review: Bound by Blood
abstract: Two siblings struggle to provide for their freakish brother in this pitch-black family drama.
lead_paragraph: In “My Heart Can’t Beat Unless You Tell It To,” director Jonathan Cuartas teams up with his brother, the cinematographer Michael Cuartas, and father, the production designer Rodrigo Cuartas, to make a film about a household of murderers. This may be dark fodder for a family project, but the result is a visually striking meditation on obligation and complicity.

headline: ‘I Carry You with Me’ Review: When You Can’t Go Home Again
abstract: The documentary filmmaker Heidi Ewing dramatizes a gay immigrant love story in this empathetic portrait.
lead_paragraph: Iván Garcia, an undocumented immigrant living in New York City, has a sad, strong face and eloquent eyes. Having risen, astonishingly, from dishwasher to chef to successful restaurateur in little over a decade, he still dreams of his home in Puebla City, Mexico, and the son he left behind. Iván has changed countries, but he hasn’t moved on.

headline: ‘Lourdes’ Review: Pilgrims Find Fellowship on Quest for Miracles
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pilgrimages', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This intimate documentary reveals the hopes and fears of those seeking healing.
lead_paragraph: Thierry Demaizière and Alban Teurlai start their documentary with imagery that is as elemental as it gets. A stone wall, slate gray, its surface sheathed, it seems, in clear water. Then, human hands, some gnarled with age, others smooth and childlike, touch the wall, sometimes with fingertips, sometimes palms.

headline: Review: ‘Sisters on Track,’ ‘LFG’ and the Price of Star Power
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Student Athlete Compensation', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Soccer', 'Track and Field']
abstract: Two documentaries explore the flaws of the financial reward systems in elite sports and their effects on the athletes involved.
lead_paragraph: Two documentaries, “Sisters on Track” and “LFG,” explore the achievements of world-class athletes and, more intriguingly, the way money is allocated within sports.

headline: ‘I Didn’t Think the Sport Wanted Me Anymore’
keywords: ['Gymnastics', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Olympic Games (2020)']
abstract: Once on the verge of throwing away her trophies in frustration, the gymnast Jordan Chiles has found her happy place — with her pal Simone Biles.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Jordan Chiles felt numb. She looked around her bedroom in Vancouver, Wash., at the dozens of medals, the rainbows of ribbons, the trophies standing in formation, all from a gymnastics career that started when she was 6.

headline: Buffett Weighs In on Tax-Free Philanthropy
abstract: The Berkshire Hathaway chief, who has given away billions, asks whether donations should keep their special status.
lead_paragraph: News yesterday that Warren Buffett had resigned from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has raised questions about the foundation’s future after the impending divorce of its namesake founders. Buffett’s resignation announcement also attracted new attention to the billions the wealthy give to charity — and the tax breaks they get for doing so.

headline: U.S. Bans Imports of Some Chinese Solar Materials Tied to Forced Labor
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Forced Labor', 'Solar Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Silicon']
abstract: Much of the world’s polysilicon, used to make solar panels, comes from Xinjiang, where the United States has accused China of committing genocide through its repression of Uyghurs.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced steps on Thursday to crack down on forced labor in the supply chain for solar panels in the Chinese region of Xinjiang, including a ban on imports from a silicon producer there.

headline: What Else Has Hong Kong Lost, Readers Ask as a Paper Is Forced to Shut
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'News and News Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Newspapers', 'Censorship']
abstract: Apple Daily, a pro-democracy news outlet, is the biggest casualty yet in Beijing’s campaign against Hong Kong’s once freewheeling news media. Its million-copy final edition sold fast.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Readers lined up in the rain to buy copies of Apple Daily’s final edition. They rushed to archive its articles online before its website went blank. Other local news outlets plastered their home pages with reports of the publication’s demise, even as editors wondered where the new boundaries lay.

headline: Biden signs on to a bipartisan infrastructure compromise, but says it must be accompanied by a larger package.
abstract: The deal is only a piece of his sprawling economic agenda, and Democrats have indicated it can only move in tandem with a much larger package of spending and tax increases.
lead_paragraph: President Biden struck an infrastructure deal on Thursday with a bipartisan group of senators, signing on to their plan to provide about $579 billion in new investments in roads, broadband internet, electric utilities and other projects in hopes of moving a crucial piece of his economic agenda through Congress.

headline: How Can I Tell My Mother-in-Law to Buzz Off?
abstract: Nothing like a non-blood relative who won’t stay away.
lead_paragraph: My partner and I live on the West Coast; our families live on the East Coast. When we go home, we make detailed plans for seeing our parents to keep our visits evenly divided and fair. Over the past few years, though, when we’re visiting my family, my partner’s mother has a habit of stopping by unannounced and staying for the day. (Once, she stayed overnight!) This upsets me; she is preventing me from spending time alone with my parents. We’ve told her these days are reserved for my family, and that my parents don’t encroach on her designated time with her son, but she continues to drop by. I want her to respect my private time with my family. Any advice?

headline: Los Angeles Gets Its Own Gallery Weekend
abstract: So far, 74 galleries and nonprofit organizations have signed on to participate in the event from the Gallery Association Los Angeles in late July.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A gallery association that formed here a year ago to promote artists online at a time when spaces were closed because of the pandemic is now organizing its first offline event: Gallery Weekend Los Angeles.

headline: A Requiem, Derailed by the Pandemic, Arrives When It’s Needed Most
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Courtney Bryan’s Requiem, premiering Thursday after its original date was canceled last year, now follows a time of loss and upheaval.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard a story like this before. Courtney Bryan’s Requiem was set to premiere with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in late March 2020. In a time of incalculable loss, her music became part of another kind of casualty: the sounds that vanished from stages around the world.

lead_paragraph: Pride celebrations in June — with their marches, parades and parties — can trace their histories back to a fiery street demonstration in 1970, the year after a violent uprising at the Stonewall Inn in Manhattan that galvanized the modern gay rights movement.

headline: A Museum Where Every Object Helped a Child Endure War

abstract: The War Childhood Museum, founded to preserve the experiences of young people in the Bosnian War of the 1990s, is expanding to reflect the wartime experiences of children everywhere.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Daria Rybalchenko was 16 when war came to her hometown, Stanytsia Luhanska, in eastern Ukraine. That summer, in 2014, she bought a copy of “The Count of Monte Cristo,” the French adventure novel by Alexandre Dumas, in Russian. She recalled reading it one evening when the sound of shelling woke her grandmother.

headline: The Best Cities for Cyclists
abstract: Bicycle riding has exploded in popularity, but the quality of your rides will vary depending on where you live.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to live longer and help slow global warming? Ride a bike. About two billion bikes are in use globally, according to the World Economic Forum, and cycling is growing in popularity, with a pandemic surge in interest creating bicycle shortages around the globe.

headline: The Bank of England stands pat as its inflation hawk dissents.

abstract: Andy Haldane, who is stepping down as the central bank’s chief economist after a three-decade career, has been concerned about rising prices.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s economic recovery is continuing apace and inflation is now expected to climb even higher than previously predicted, but the Bank of England’s policymakers stood firm on Thursday and saw little need to scale back their large monetary stimulus program.

headline: Beer Cans and Baseball Caps Fly as Islanders Force a Game 7
abstract: After giving up a 2-0 lead, New York scored three straight goals, including one by Anthony Beauvillier in overtime, to steal a must-win Game 6.
lead_paragraph: The debris came soaring out of the stands — beer cans, water bottles, towels, a couple of baseball caps, two gray shoes and a pair of glasses, whatever was handy.

headline: A Very Hot Year
abstract: The warmth we’ve added to the atmosphere — the heat equivalent, each day, of 400,000 Hiroshima-sized bombs — is already producing truly dire effects, decades or even centuries ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: The warmth we’ve added to the atmosphere — the heat equivalent, each day, of 400,000 Hiroshima-sized bombs — is already producing truly dire effects, decades or even centuries ahead of schedule.

headline: How Basquiat and Street Artists Left Their Mark on Hip-Hop Culture
abstract: A dozen artists, most of them Black or Latino, are the subjects of an exhibition that aims to correct oversights in art history.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — By 1984, 24-year-old Jean-Michel Basquiat had already broken into the mainstream art world. But the onetime street artist still couldn’t shake the legacy of his teenage years spent writing graffiti on the streets of New York City — mostly under the moniker of “SAMO,” which he often used to critique the commodification of art.

headline: ‘Sun Children’ Review: Treasure Hunt
abstract: Majid Majidi’s social-realist drama about street children in Iran trades narrative complexity for precious visuals.
lead_paragraph: “Sun Children” opens with a series of striking shots. A montage rifles through images of swanky car hoods as a band of pint-size carjackers try to find their pick in a garage; a boy runs through Tehran, the streets rippling around him like water; kids frolic in a circular pool that, shot from above, sparkles like a blue sun. Majid Majidi’s latest feature doesn’t lack in style or charm, using a child’s perspective — a staple in Iranian cinema — to locate beauty and hope in a cynical world. As is often the case with the director’s work, however, precious visuals come at the cost of narrative complexity.

lead_paragraph: In 2017, a telescope in Hawaii noticed a strange object careering through the solar system. Was it just a weirdly behaving comet? Loeb, a prominent astrophysicist at Harvard, came to a bolder conclusion: The object, christened “Oumuamua” (Hawaiian for “scout”), could well be the product of an alien civilization — the first proof of intelligent life outside our planet. “If we dare to wager that Oumuamua was a piece of advanced extraterrestrial technology, we stand only to gain,” he writes in this book arguing his case, which doubles as a poignant memoir of his childhood on an Israeli farm and his passion for space science.

headline: Why Is It OK to Be Mean to the Ugly?
abstract: Lookism starts, like every form of bigotry, with prejudice and stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: A manager sits behind a table and decides he’s going to fire a woman because he doesn’t like her skin. If he fires her because her skin is brown, we call that racism and there is legal recourse. If he fires her because her skin is female, we call that sexism and there is legal recourse. If he fires her because her skin is pockmarked and he finds her unattractive, well, we don’t talk about that much and, in most places in America, there is no legal recourse.

abstract: The president has long pitched himself as both solidly progressive and committed to bipartisanship. His deal with Republicans, coupled with assurances to liberals, attempts to marry the two.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s bipartisan infrastructure agreement contains all of the contradictions and promises of the Biden brand. It is a deal that dramatically curbs Democrats’ policy goals in the pursuit of bipartisanship, but also opens a portal to what could be the most ambitious expansion of government into the economy in decades.

headline: Where Did the Coronavirus Come From? What We Already Know Is Troubling.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Research', 'Bats', 'Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Even if the coronavirus did not emerge from a lab, the groundwork for a potential disaster had been laid for years, and learning its lessons is essential to preventing others.
lead_paragraph: There were curious characteristics about the H1N1 influenza pandemic of 1977-78, which emerged from northeastern Asia and killed an estimated 700,000 people around the world. For one, it almost exclusively affected people in their mid-20s or younger. Scientists discovered another oddity that could explain the first: It was virtually identical to a strain that circulated in the 1950s. People born before that had immunity that protected them, and younger people didn’t.

headline: I Created ‘The X-Files.’ Here’s Why I’m Skeptical of the New U.F.O. Report.
keywords: ['Extraterrestrial Life', 'Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Could the government actually be telling the truth? Or is the truth above top secret?” asks “X-Files” creator Chris Carter.
lead_paragraph: When we were dressing the original set for Agent Mulder’s office on “The X-Files,” I came up with the poster with a U.F.O. on it that reads “I Want to Believe.” And I think that’s where most people come down on the whole extraterrestrial business. Not quite there yet, but waiting for a sign.

headline: Finding a Love Connection on Zoom
abstract: Cheri Spigner and Tracey Syphax were married at Philadelphia’s National Constitution Center after spending a history-making pandemic year getting to know each other on and off line.
lead_paragraph: On May 22, after the planning was finished, the attire selected, the menu carefully curated and the guests assembled, Cheri D. Spigner had a moment to stand on a balcony and get a covert, bird’s-eye view of her wedding ceremony. Guests were neatly arranged, seated on chairs that formed a pair of circles around an altar. Two of the chairs lay empty: A tribute to Ms. Spigner’s mother and father, who are both deceased. Ms. Spigner’s mother had died earlier that month. So when Ms. Spigner saw the empty chairs, she said, she “almost started crying.” For comfort, she locked her eyes on her soon-to-be husband, Tracey D. Syphax, who stood at the altar.

headline: Rome Finds There’s No Accounting for Taste, Artistic or Culinary
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Vegetarianism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Pigs', 'Art']
abstract: A new set of public artworks was supposed to pay tribute to the Italian capital, but a sculpture of a roasted pig has raised the hackles of animal rights groups and finnicky Romans.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The new artworks in eight of central Rome’s public squares are meant to be playful celebrations of the city’s rich culture and history. But some very vocal people do not see the whimsy in a dead pig.

headline: On the Front Line: A Night With Afghan Commandos
abstract: On a recent night raid, a Times photographer captured Afghanistan’s elite forces as they disrupted Taliban operations in one of the country’s most volatile provinces.
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE OVER HELMAND PROVINCE, Afghanistan — As the city lights faded and the Soviet-era military helicopter banked over the fields and canals of southern Afghanistan one night in May, the Afghan commandos on board made their final checks, looking at maps and adjusting their weapons before turning on their night-vision goggles.

headline: Carl Nassib Is Seeking His Path as an Out Athlete
abstract: Nassib, the N.F.L. player who made history this week when he came out as gay, has long yearned to make a difference in the world.
lead_paragraph: Carl Nassib was not the most eager interview subject on Penn State’s football team. He once begged off a media scrum by claiming he had a chemistry exam, which was not strictly true, though he was known to rhapsodize more about “recrystallization as a purification mechanism” than the minutiae of Purdue’s off-tackle trap.

headline: The Lesbian Avengers Will Not Be Commodified
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'T-Shirts (Apparel)', 'Logos']
abstract: At least, not by the Gap.
lead_paragraph: Among the many rainbow-colored products and sparkly knickknacks for sale during Pride month this year, a T-shirt briefly available from the Gap stood out for its sober design. Printed on a plain white crew neck with short sleeves was a bomb encircled by the words “The Lesbian Avengers.”

headline: The Dynamics of College Sports Are Changing. So Are the Business Prospects.
keywords: ['Student Athlete Compensation', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Basketball (College)', 'College Athletics']
abstract: Some digital opportunities didn’t exist even a few years ago, but now are part of what young athletes will be evaluating as they consider where, or whether, to go to college.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — After playing five basketball games in less than 48 hours, Dereck Lively II slung a gym bag over his shoulder and headed for the exit at the corrugated metal warehouse where he had spent much of the last three days performing in front of N.B.A. scouts.

headline: Christian Slater Is a Still-Life Artist
abstract: The former teen idol actor talks about his career comeback, being a father again and sketching his wife.
lead_paragraph: John Varriano, an instructor at the Art Students League, stood behind Christian Slater’s easel, studying the lines that the 51-year-old actor had sketched. “You have chops, man,” Mr. Varriano said. “You have got to keep practicing, man.”

headline: What I Saw in My First 10 Years on Testosterone
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Testosterone', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Whether we asked for the job or not, trans people are playing a key role in shaping the future of gender for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago this month, on an otherwise ordinary lunch break from my job as an editor at a local newspaper, I received my first testosterone injection from a no-nonsense doctor at a hospital in Boston. I was 30 years old and desperate to be known.

headline: Specialized Experiences Offer Fresh Looks on Paris
keywords: ['Walking', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Champagne (Wine)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: As visitors trickle back into the city after a heavy year, walking tours and other experiences that emphasize seldom-told stories about local life and history are taking on new resonance.
lead_paragraph: As the second-most visited city in the world (that is, prepandemic), Paris has always meant brisk business when it comes to guided tours and excursions for travelers. From historical walks and cooking classes to outings that grant exclusive access to artists’ workshops, museum archives and private mansions, there are activities for almost any interest.

headline: A Labor of Love Side by Side
abstract: Dr. Jessica Fields, an obstetrician-gynecologist, and Maggie Sensenig, a labor and delivery nurse, met on the job.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jessica Chaplin Fields and Margaret Louise Sensenig have delivered dozens of babies side by side — including for close friends and Dr. Fields’s sister — at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. Now they plan to start a family of their own.

headline: The Reluctant Rider’s Guide to Biking
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Content Type: Service', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Cycling, Mountain Bike', 'Exercise', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Cycling, Road']
abstract: The cycling world can be intimidating, even for those who grew up in it. But that’s no reason to let your pandemic wheels gather dust.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been a passionate, mediocre bicyclist most of my life. I’ve done 100-mile rides and placed nearly dead last, thanks to extended milkshake stops. I can replace an inner tube in 60 minutes flat, with only moderate cursing. I once broke my hip on a mountain bike after launching 10 feet through the air off a jump that I didn’t even know was there.

headline: A Brooklyn Ice Cream Shop and the Make-or-Break Summer Ahead
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Small Business', 'Family Business', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Summer (Season)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Crème and Cocoa Creamery survived the pandemic. But like many small businesses in New York, its future is hardly secure.
lead_paragraph: It is here at last, the summer of possibility. New York City has been flung open. The evenings have grown long and sultry. Block parties are happening, sidewalks are buzzy. Joy subsists on the chance to roam, to linger.

headline: Why Washington Can’t Quit Listening to Larry Summers
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'American Rescue Plan (2021)']
abstract: A longtime leading man of economics is no longer making America’s policies. He’s still driving a critical conversation around them.
lead_paragraph: Larry Summers has split his pandemic time between houses in Massachusetts and Arizona. He also seems to live inside the collective mind of the Washington economic establishment.

headline: My Pandemic Hobby? Making Money.
abstract: During Covid, many people found solace in a new pastime. A few found profit.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Eisler learned to knit in the first grade, and was good at it. She also did time as a Girl Scout, which imbued her with an admirable can-do spirit.

headline: Is This Some Kind of Code? You Can Solve the …

lead_paragraph: The verb “puzzle” — to perplex or confuse, bewilder or bemuse — is of unknown origin. “That kind of fits,” said Martin Demaine, an artist in residence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. “It’s a puzzle where the word ‘puzzle’ comes from.”

headline: 21 Easy Summer Dinners You’ll Cook (or Throw Together) on Repeat
abstract: Some assembly — but no oven — required.
lead_paragraph: When temperatures soar above 80 degrees, it’s OK to use the word “cook” loosely. This time of year, dinners are often made on the fly anyway, tossed together after a day at a park or by a pool. The New York Times Cooking recipes below stick to those unwritten rules of summer cooking: They must be bright and quick, with absolutely no oven required.

headline: ‘No Shortcuts?’: A 40-Mile Rite of Passage for High School Freshmen
abstract: A year after the pandemic canceled a nearly 50-year-old tradition, a New Jersey Catholic school brought back a mandatory hike across the Appalachian Trail.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Luna, a freshman at St. Benedict’s Prep in Newark, stood along a brook in Stokes State Forest as he scanned a paper map of the Appalachian Trail’s rocky path across New Jersey’s northwest corner.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Suhendro Sastrowiwoho was fully vaccinated and eager to help this month as Indonesia faced a new and deadly wave of Delta variant coronavirus cases. His daughter and son-in-law, both trained as doctors, told him to rest. He was 74 years old, they warned, and the virus was evolving in unexpected ways.

headline: A Road Map to Infrastructure

lead_paragraph: Months ago, President Biden unveiled the centerpiece of his domestic agenda: a two-pronged, $4 trillion effort to transform the U.S. economy by overhauling the nation’s infrastructure and expanding aid to families.

headline: ‘Fathom’ Review: A Whale of a Conversation
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Research', 'Animal Cognition']
abstract: Scientists attempt to communicate with humpback whales in this Apple TV+ documentary.
lead_paragraph: “Fathom,” a curiosity-driven documentary by Drew Xanthopoulos, is fascinated by two types of waves. It opens with a small boat on an overwhelming vista of water, then cuts to a computer analysis of the visual patterns in whale songs two scientists have left their lives behind to record.

headline: Review: A Darkly Satirical Glimpse Into Life ‘Off Broadway’
abstract: Torrey Townsend’s backstage fiction is an indictment of the real world’s overwhelmingly white, disproportionately male theatrical establishment.
lead_paragraph: It is the fall of 2020, and the American National Theater is desperate to survive the pandemic.

headline: ‘Wolfgang’ Review: Light as a Soufflé, and About as Substantial
abstract: David Gelb’s biographical documentary says much about what Wolfgang Puck has done, and very little about who he is
lead_paragraph: “I don’t like to think about the past too much,” Wolfgang Puck confesses early in the Disney+ documentary “Wolfgang,” a red flag that we’re not going to encounter much in the way of intense self-scrutiny in the scant 78 minutes that follow. A fairly vapid and shallow affair, even by the low standards of the celebrity bio-doc subgenre, “Wolfgang” provides copious archival montages of “the first celebrity chef” (Julia Child apparently didn’t count), but precious little understanding of what actually makes him tick.

headline: Banks’ Billion-Dollar Rewards for Passing Their Exams
abstract: Successfully clearing their latest Fed stress tests will free them to resume huge stock buybacks.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen of the nation’s largest lenders, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, yesterday passed the Fed’s annual test of whether they could survive a severe economic downturn. Last year, during the height of the pandemic, Wall Street’s six largest banks earned a collective $81 billion. They can clearly survive, and thrive, through some pretty significant stress. That is good news — but the risk is that it leads to lenders and policymakers letting their guards down as conditions improve.

lead_paragraph: Just as people are beginning to squeeze into form-fitting clothes again, the shapewear brand Spanx has tapped Goldman Sachs to explore options including a sale, reports the DealBook newsletter, based on multiple sources familiar with the situation.

headline: Grammys Settle With Ousted C.E.O.

lead_paragraph: Few people relish the idea of living through a home renovation. The work is loud, dusty, and completely upends your life. Live through one during a pandemic, though, and you face an additional challenge: There’s no escape.

headline: Rita Moreno: Pathbreaker, Activist and ‘A Kick in the Pants’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Actors and Actresses']
abstract: The actress discusses being the subject of a new documentary, and spending eight-plus decades in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Rita Moreno was all of 6 when she made her professional debut, duetting with her Spanish dance instructor on a stage in Greenwich Village. “I remember every detail,” she said. She wore a traditional, resplendently ruffled dress. “We danced a jota — that was a country dance. And we played castanets. My mom let me put on lipstick — I was so thrilled.” It was 1937.

headline: Belarus Transfers Opposition Figure to House Arrest

lead_paragraph: As India begins to reopen after a devastating second wave of coronavirus infections, concern among virologists is growing that another, possibly more virulent version of the virus could hasten the start of a third wave within just a few months.

headline: Biden will reverse a Trump border policy put in place during the pandemic.

headline: Alone in the Temporary New Ruins of Rome
abstract: The museums are open. Few visitors have returned. It’s beautiful, but it can’t stay like this.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The most enduring images of this city after cataclysm were printed a little over 250 years ago, by the artist Giovanni Battista Piranesi. His “Ruins of Rome” etchings depict landmarks like the Pantheon and the Castel Sant’Angelo, but its most famous images show rubble-strewn gardens and crumbling bridges, and tricorn-hatted gentlemen wandering through collapsed temples and overgrown ossuaries. For 18th-century philosophers and noblemen on the Grand Tour, the dramas of “Ruins of Rome” made a point about the transience of civilization — but they were, even more than that, a high-end tourist guide. The good days are over, but come anyway; Rome’s cooler with no people.

headline: Ilana Glazer on the Terror of the Modern Birth System and ‘False Positive’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses']

headline: A Graceful Place Where Bhangra and Bollywood Meet
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Punjabi (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Manpreet Toor, who has found success on YouTube and TikTok, reflects a new wave of Indian diaspora dance.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in California, Manpreet Toor remembers being exposed to bhangra — a lively Punjabi dance genre that is performed widely in the Indian diaspora — in her parents’ garage. “In Punjabi households, back in the day, we used to have parties in the garage all the time,” Toor said. She heard the sounds of music like the folk and pop artist Sardool Sikander, one of India’s most beloved singers, who died of Covid-19 in February.

headline: Wait, Who’s Fast, Who’s Furious?
abstract: A guide to the characters and the melodramas in the sprawling, surprisingly complicated “Fast & Furious” franchise.
lead_paragraph: At one point, rather a long time ago now, the “Fast & Furious” movies were about street racing. They do still involve cars moving at breakneck speeds, but only as one component in a blockbuster machine that also routinely includes high-stakes espionage, military-grade shootouts, multimillion-dollar bank heists and villainous schemes for global annihilation. They lately have more in common with James Bond or “Mission: Impossible” than with “Gone in 60 Seconds.”

headline: Stephen Dunn, Poet Who Celebrated the Ordinary, Dies at 82

lead_paragraph: Stephen Dunn, whose plain-spoken poems about the small things in life and the bigger things within them filled numerous collections, one of which, “Different Hours,” won the Pulitzer Prize in 2001, died on Thursday, his 82nd birthday, at his home in Frostburg, Md.

lead_paragraph: Good morning. After more than a year of social distancing, Gabrielle Hamilton wanted to reclaim the notion of “six feet,” give it a new context, make people laugh with delight while she fed them lunch. So she wrote a recipe for a six-foot hero (above) that calls to mind the Italian hoagies of her youth, albeit one that doesn’t contain capicola, soppressata or deli ham.

headline: Humble Waiter or Son of a King? A Royal Mystery Piques Spain.

headline: A Painting of a Fiery Being From a Parallel Universe

abstract: A timeline of key moments for understanding the far right in modern Germany.

headline: Rauw Alejandro Draws a Fresh Blueprint for Spanish-Language Pop

lead_paragraph: “¿Cuándo fue?,” the 10th track from Rauw Alejandro’s new album “Vice Versa,” provides an unexpected jolt. As the Puerto Rican singer mourns the departure of a lover, the producer Tainy blends rivulets of synths and delicate percussion, allowing them to bleed into a hiss of hot air. Suddenly, a skittish breakbeat drops, plunging the track into rave territory. The transition is like a static shock, the equivalent of shuffling across the floor in warm socks and touching a doorknob.

headline: Consider Loving Midtown Instead of Hating It
abstract: As awe-inspiring as the emptiness of 2020 was, it’s the people (yes, those we exasperatedly call crowds when commuting) who make me feel at home.
lead_paragraph: I was born and raised in New York City. After I moved away in the middle of the pandemic, I was surprised by how much I didn’t miss it — even the things that I felt I obviously might miss. I didn’t miss the Manhattan skyline or my 24-hour fruit market. I didn’t even miss my friends, probably because I moved when the pandemic was still raging, so it’s not as if I had seen any of them recently. I barely missed the easy access to good bagels and good pizza.

Since its founding in 2016, the organization has moved beyond just restaurants to showcase all kinds of businesses, from food trucks to caterers to bakeries. Specials can be found on the list of participants, and New Yorkers will be able to vote for their favorites in the inaugural Black Plate Awards. At the Boogie Down Grind cafe in Hunts Point in the Bronx, the owner Majora Carter added live music for a Saturday night event. She decided to participate this year after hearing about last year’s campaign. The exposure has generated better business for the cafe, Ms. Carter said. “On this 100th anniversary of the Tulsa massacre, it’s so important we establish the value of support for all Black-owned businesses,” Ms. Carter said. “It’s time.”

headline: Robert Gottlieb on the Man Who Saw America (And We Mean, All of It)
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: In 1947, the legendary journalist John Gunther published “Inside U.S.A.,” a best-selling 900-page portrait of the country. Robert Gottlieb revisits the book, revealing a reporter with an eagle eye and a limitless appetite for facts.
lead_paragraph: Almost 75 years ago John Gunther produced his amazing profile of our country, “Inside U.S.A.” — more than 900 pages long, and still riveting from start to finish. It started out with a first printing of 125,000 copies — the largest first printing in the history of Harper & Brothers — plus 380,000 more for the Book-of-the-Month Club. It was the third-biggest nonfiction best seller of 1947 (ahead of it, only Rabbi Joshua Loth Liebman’s “Peace of Mind” and the “Information Please Almanac”). It was a phenomenon, but not a surprise: Gunther’s first great success, “Inside Europe,” published in 1936, had helped alert the world to the realities of fascism and Stalinism; “Inside Asia” and “Inside Latin America” followed, with comparable success — all three of these books were among the top sellers of their year, as would be “Inside Africa” and “Inside Russia Today,” yet to come. His “Roosevelt in Retrospect” (1950) is one of the best political biographies I’ve ever come across, a mere 400 pages long and pure pleasure to read. Like “Inside U.S.A.,” it is out of print — please, American publishers, one of you make them reappear.

abstract: Given the depth of quality in Europe, a small expansion (and a simpler format) could make for a much better tournament.

headline: Escapist, Easygoing Pieces for Unstructured Days
abstract: Attersee, a new line of breezy clothing and accessories, was partly inspired by Gustav Klimt’s summer trips to the foothills of the Austrian Alps.
lead_paragraph: In the early years of the last century, when the August heat settled over the sweltering streets of Vienna, Gustav Klimt would head westward to the foothills of the Alps, where he’d paint slender birch trees and other tranquil landscapes, study his Japanese art books and swim in the clear waters of Attersee, one of Austria’s largest lakes. He’d paint from the lake, too, often piloting a small rowboat, oils and canvas in tow, out onto its mineral-blue surface. Immersed in nature, he’d exchange his city clothes for an ankle-length caftan — a free-flowing garment to match his unstructured days.

headline: Dijon or Nothing
abstract: A new book celebrates Burgundian mustard, with recipes.
lead_paragraph: That July Fourth hot dog will probably be slathered with everyday yellow, but for more refined preparations, it’s Dijon that’s in demand. The city in France’s Burgundy region south of Paris, the center of French mustard production today, is just one stop on the journey that mustard has taken over 5,000 years, becoming a favorite condiment worldwide. This lively book traces the history, focusing on France and notably on Maison Fallot, a traditional Burgundian producer. There are also recipes for 40 dishes, many of them complex creations like Daniel Boulud’s Chaud-Froid of Free-Range Poularde that consists of nine separate recipes, not including plating. Others are appealingly simple, including pork tenderloin with Dijon mustard sauce from Christophe Muller of the Paul Bocuse flagship restaurant.

headline: Gin from Cachaça Country
abstract: Amázzoni makes use of the Brazil nut and cocoa in its London dry-style spirit.
lead_paragraph: Gin, made around the world, comes in two basic styles: austere, juniper-forward London dry, and a more aromatic herbal or floral version. For a martini and perhaps even with tonic, it’s the London dry you’ll want and, more specifically, this alluringly subtle Brazilian gin, Amázzoni, newly available in the United States. It leans on botanicals like Brazil nut, Victoria regia (a type of water lily) and cocoa. The distillery is on an 18th century coffee farm in the Paraíba Valley northwest of Rio de Janeiro. The gin is excellent on the rocks, perhaps with a few açai berries added for that Amazonian garnish.

abstract: Bklyn Clay has added a pop of color to its dinnerware line.
lead_paragraph: Bklyn Clay, a ceramics studio that offers classes and sells ceramics and materials for potters, has introduced a line of practical stoneware bowls and plates in several sizes. The collection, initially offered in white, now includes satin or glossy finishes, speckled or not, in a range of colors, including celadon, saddle, saffron and a shade of royal blue called cosmo. The plates can be used as covers for the bowls and the pieces are safe in the dishwasher or microwave. Though they’re suitable for everyday use, the price suggests the special occasion category at $40 to $60 per piece, with five-piece dinnerware sets ranging from $255 to $1,020.

headline: Cocktail Bites With a European Twist
abstract: Cheesy gratins are the latest in Savorly’s line of frozen hors d’oeuvres.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn company Savorly’s line of frozen hors d’oeuvres, created in Belgium and France, can be quickly heated in the oven or air fryer for an array of colorful and tasty puff pastry mini-pies, mini-tarts and cocktail bites. They’re mostly filled with vegetable mixtures, and sometimes with cheese, but no meat or seafood. Newest are the mini gratins: cauliflower and broccoli, and, my favorite, potato and cheese. These, served two or three per person, make for excellent sides with a steak or fish off the grill. There are six to 20 pieces per box.

headline: The Translucent History of Wine
abstract: The Corning Museum of Glass in western New York features a new exhibition on wine.
lead_paragraph: If your summer road trip takes you to New York’s Southern Tier, along the border with Pennsylvania, or to the Finger Lakes wine country, plan a stop in Corning, the city known for glassware and home of the vast collection in its Museum of Glass. Starting Saturday and running through the end of next year, there’s a new exhibit that explores the connection between glass and wine, from ancient Rome to the present. lead_paragraph: What is poetry for? It might be the overwhelming question of poetry, to borrow Prufrock’s turn of phrase. What does it do, why does it matter, how can it matter, what is it for? Because reading a poem is less fun for most people than watching a movie or listening to music, it seems to need to justify itself as an art form, to offer some cultural use value above and beyond pleasure. Hence the enduring popularity of “I, too, dislike it” and “Poetry makes nothing happen” in essays on the uselessness, the hatred of poetry — suggesting that these lines, at least out of context, do have some use value.

headline: Race Manners: Which Black People Should I Believe?
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: White people are often admonished to defer to Black people on issues of race and racism. But Black people don’t hold monolithic opinions. What to do?
lead_paragraph: One of the most common pieces of advice I’ve heard given to aspiring white allies is to seek out more Black opinions. This advice is often coupled with a further admonition to suspend one’s own judgment and simply defer to Black people on matters of race and racism. However, Black Americans are a diverse group with a wide range of opinions on matters related to race and racism. As a result I have seen this advice result in paralysis of judgment and also the elevation of some bad ideas that come from the “right” people. If we asked Kimberlé Crenshaw, Adolph Reed, John McWhorter, Angela Davis and Tim Scott all to weigh in on “defund the police,” we’d get five different answers. What advice do you have for prospective and aspiring white allies about evaluating media from diverse sources and ultimately drawing their own conclusions?

headline: Igor Levit on Frederic Rzewski: ‘The People’s Composer’
abstract: Rzewski, who died on Saturday, could be a prickly contrarian. But for some young artists, including Levit, he was an essential inspiration.
lead_paragraph: The composer Frederic Rzewski, who died on Saturday at 83, left behind a complicated legacy. He wrote intensely political works but didn’t identify as a political artist. In the hours after his death was announced, some musicians described him on social media as warm and encouraging, others as prickly and sometimes troubling. Yet his stature in the field is immense, with contributions to the piano repertoire like “The People United Will Never Be Defeated!” — a titanic set of variations on Sergio Ortega and Quilapayún’s Chilean resistance song “¡El pueblo unido jamás será vencido!” He also had a widespread influence on a younger generation of performers and composers. Among them is the pianist Igor Levit, who elevated “The People United” to the realm of Bach’s “Goldberg” and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations on a celebrated 2015 recording. In an interview, Levit said, “I cannot overstate the importance of this man in my life,” and he shared memories as thorny as Rzewski himself. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: When James Baldwin Was a ‘Has-Been’

Baldwin is poised, attentive and beguiling as he speaks to Sylvia Chase, a correspondent for the ABC newsmagazine “20/20.” Across the segment, we see him grinning as he watches a rehearsal of his play “The Amen Corner”; we see him speaking to a group of children in Harlem; we see B-roll of him outside, catching his scarf before it’s swept away by the wind. Toward the end, the writer’s mother, siblings, nieces and nephews gather on a sofa and chairs around him. “There’s a price this republic exacts from any Black man or woman walking,” Baldwin asserts, “and that is a crime.” He reaches for the child seated next to him on the sofa. “They will not do to him,” he says, “what they failed to do to me.” We meet his unblinking gaze as his words resonate. “I was 7 years old 47 years ago,” he says, “and nothing has changed since then.”

headline: ‘China Has Risen.’ And It Is Hungry for Competition.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Competition with China could mean benefits for the United States, if we learn the right lessons of history.
lead_paragraph: When the Soviet Union crumbled in the 1990s, Americans did a victory lap that lasted for decades. We saw it as the triumph of capitalism over communism, freedom over authoritarianism, democracy over one-party rule. We assumed that the game was over and that we had won. We had reached “the end of history.” We thought that it was only a matter of time before China, which had already embraced some free-market reforms, transitioned to a system just like ours. Americans normalized trade with China and waited patiently for the “Chinese Gorbachev.” If you’re still out there waiting, don’t hold your breath.

abstract: For years as a journalist, I’ve covered attempts to exonerate incarcerated people. But a letter from Yutico Briley led to a different kind of story.

For a couple of years, Oehler and Briley had been writing to each other through a support program for incarcerated people. She wanted to let me know that Briley was trying to reach me. “In his last letter to me, he said he’d written to you at The Times but wasn’t sure if you received the letter,” Oehler explained.

headline: ‘America: The Motion Picture’ Review: In Bros We Trust
abstract: The American Revolution gets a frat-style sendup in this irreverent animated comedy.
lead_paragraph: Two nights before signing the Declaration of Independence, George Washington threw a celebratory rager where America’s founding father was said to have rung up a bar tab equivalent to $17,253. Our nation began with a hangover, a fact too factual to be included in “America: The Motion Picture” (streaming on Netflix), a raunchy, aggressively inane cartoon that flips the bird — both onscreen and thematically — to a strain of patriotism that insists that men who profited from slavery were sober-minded heroes whose vision of democracy remains flawless, bro. “That’s why we make the rules, baby!” bellows Samuel Adams (voiced by Jason Mantzoukas) after a keg stand. Here, to be a privileged white man in America is intoxicating, a truth no less fictional than watching Paul Revere win a “Fast and Furious”-inspired street race that goes “one quarter-mule at a time.”

headline: Inside Betsey Johnson’s Malibu Dream House
abstract: The designer gives T a tour of her pretty but punk home in one of California’s most scenic trailer parks.
lead_paragraph: The thing about pink, Betsey Johnson will tell you, is that it contains subtleties, so you’ve got to get specific. For the facade of her house in Malibu, California’s Point Dume Club — a gated trailer park set on a bluff jutting toward the Pacific, about 200 feet below — she gave the painter a swatch that wasn’t Day-Glo pink, the color she chose for the kitchen at her vacation home in Barra de Potosí, Mexico, in the 1990s, or the bright bubble gum pink she selected for her Manhattan loft in the 1980s. Rather, she says, “the shade was close to a ballerina, with a touch of salmon.” But the precise tone, she explains, changes each day along with the light, taking on a bit of the dusty rose and orange Creamsicle of the sun as it sets. That Johnson would opt for some kind of pink, however, was never really in question. As she puts it, “When it comes down to it, what other color could my house be?”

headline: Over 200 Million Years Ago, Nature Called. It Was Full of Beetles.

R.I.P. — but on the bright side, through a complex combination of luck and microbial activity, their tiny corpses become frozen in time. And over 200 million years later, scientists uncover them while rooting around in fossilized feces.

headline: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Assume Vivid Astro Focus at Tibor de Nagy, “Field of Vision” at Peter Blum and “The Poet-Engineers” at Miguel Abreu.
lead_paragraph: It’s been seven years since the duo known as Assume Vivid Astro Focus has had a show in New York. But this exuberant comeback effort, “Hairy What? Hairy How?” at Tibor de Nagy, is also a solo debut. Its four large semiabstract paintings and a painted table — all lavishly fringed with wool yarn and surrounded by numerous smaller unfringed pieces — are the work of the Brazilian artist Eli Sudbrack, one half of Assume Vivid Astro Focus. He formed it in New York in 2001 with Christophe Hamaide-Pierson, a French artist. These days the pair functions as much independently as together, but always under the collective’s name. This confuses, yet makes sense: Both sensibilities are rooted in the hallucinatory, multi-style, multimedia environments they concocted all over the globe for nearly two decades.

headline: Mae West Vamped and Winked. She Also Blazed a Trail We’re Still Following.

lead_paragraph: Mae West is fourth-billed in her film debut, the 1932 melodrama “Night After Night,” and she doesn’t appear until the 37-minute mark. But it’s an unforgettable entrance.
